content.webTitle: Marc Albrighton relishes support of neutrals for Leicester City’s title charge

fields.headline: Marc Albrighton relishes support of neutrals for Leicester City’s title charge
fields.bodyText: Marc Albrighton needs no telling that the goodwill towards Leicester City stretches far and wide these days. From conversations with rival supporters to the colourful stamps on his fan mail, the winger has seen for himself how a narrative that belongs to a different era has captured the imagination of football followers everywhere. “We get letters through from all parts of the world – Vietnam, China, America, Scotland. They’re all pretty much on the same lines, that they’re over the moon at what we’re doing this season and congratulating us on what we’ve achieved,” he says. “Every neutral, and just people in general, want Leicester to do well. I know fans of Arsenal and Manchester City who have said to me: ‘We’d love you to go on and win the title or to get into the top four’. It just goes to show not only that we’re doing well and upsetting the rhythm of the Premier League but they can see what a good club it is. If it wasn’t people wouldn’t want you to do well.” Bottom of the table this time last year, Leicester have already won the battle for hearts and minds in an extraordinary title race. Claudio Ranieri’s side travel to second-placed Manchester City on Saturday and – let this soak in for a moment – would go a minimum of five points clear with 13 games remaining if they can following up Tuesday’s win over Liverpool with another victory. Not that anyone at Leicester is getting carried away. Ranieri has already ruled out adopting Barack Obama’s ‘Yes we can’ slogan from the US president’s 2008 campaign and Leicester’s players are too busy trying to make sense of everything to be swept along with the hype. “We stay grounded because, to be honest, we’re as shocked as everybody else to be in this situation,” Albrighton says. “We knew we had a great side and we knew we could do something special, but not in our wildest dreams could we have thought we’d be in this position at this stage of the season. Our target was just staying in the league.” With their aggressive pressing, incredible work ethic and ability to counterattack with such pace, Leicester have struck upon a winning formula. Albrighton talks about learning from their Boxing Day defeat at Anfield, where they were uncharacteristically passive, and how on Tuesday against the same opponents they “came out all guns blazing from the first whistle, got in their face and showed them no respect”. Released by Aston Villa 21 months ago – a blessing in disguise if ever there was one – Albrighton sounds like he is relishing his new lease of life in the east midlands. After making such a positive impact at the end of last term, he has started all but one of Leicester’s league games this season and is one of several unsung heroes in a team where “nobody takes themselves too seriously”. The dressing room, he says, is not short of characters. Jamie Vardy is the life and soul of the party, according to the former Villa winger, with Kasper Schmeichel not far behind. The comedy value is provided by Robert Huth’s dry sense of humour while N’Golo Kanté, who has been such a revelation this season, is a picture of happiness. “I don’t think I’ve ever seen NG when he hasn’t been smiling, no matter what. He could be late for a meeting or late to training and someone will say: ‘You’re fined £200’, and he will just have a massive grin across his face,” Albrighton says, laughing. “On the pitch he runs through everything and tackles. He has been tremendous for us.” Alongside Vardy and Riyad Mahrez, Kanté is arguably one of three outstanding individuals in the Leicester team that will start at the Etihad and has been put together at a total cost of about £21m. Or, to put it another way, half as much as City paid for Eliaquim Mangala. Although Albrighton suspects some of Leicester’s players “wouldn’t fit in at a Man City because it’s a different style of play”, he has no doubt that at least two of his team-mates could get a game for one of the elite clubs. “Vardy and Riyad would walk into any other team. How they haven’t got a player like Vardy, who will run in behind and stretch a defence, is beyond me, because it’s one of the best weapons you can have in a team. And you’ve got Mahrez, who can do anything on his day.” As for Albrighton, the 26-year-old admits he is a different player to the one that broke through and showed such promise at Villa under Gérard Houllier back in the 2010-11 season. “I’ve had to adapt my game a little bit. With my injuries as well, I don’t know whether I’ve lost a bit of pace, I’m not as confident to run past a player any more, whereas I’m more confident in my crossing ability. I feel like I’ve worked on that more since I burst on the scene.” Villa’s disastrous position gives him no pleasure. Born in Tamworth, Albrighton grew up supporting the club that is anchored to the foot of the table – he went to watch them in the FA Cup semi-final last season – and it seems strange to think he could be running out to the sound of the Champions League anthem at a time when Villa are playing in the Championship. “My first hope is that we can do something big, but then I hope that something can get sorted at Villa Park,” he says. “I don’t think it’s right that a club as big as that could be playing in the Championship. It just goes to show that you are never too big to go down and a bit of arrogance has probably cost them in the end.” Albrighton remembers what it was like for Leicester when they were marooned at the bottom last season and says that the pressure of being in a relegation battle, when “everything was riding on it”, is so much greater than anything they are experiencing at the top of the table. At the same time, Albrighton fully appreciates this is once-in-a-lifetime territory for Leicester and that they have to seize their chance. “The manager has told us that we need to enjoy the moment but make sure that we don’t waste what we’re doing because next year will be totally different,” Albrighton says. “Chelsea, Manchester United, even Liverpool, they’ll be back up to the standards they set previously, so it’s going to be a lot harder, so we might not get this position again. We need to take advantage of it now.”
